Community Land Trusts: A community land trust (CLT) is a nonprofit organization that holds and manages land for the benefit of a community. CLTs can provide affordable housing, promote community control over land use, and ensure that housing remains affordable in the long term.

Micro-unit Housing: Micro-unit housing refers to small, efficient dwelling units that are typically between 150 and 300 square feet in size. These units can be built in urban areas and can provide an affordable housing option for individuals who cannot afford larger units.

Co-living Spaces: Co-living spaces are shared living environments that provide a communal living experience. These spaces can include shared kitchens, common areas, and shared amenities, such as laundry facilities and recreational spaces. Co-living spaces can provide an affordable housing option and can also foster a sense of community among residents.

Public-Private Partnerships: Public-private partnerships can be used to develop affordable housing. In these partnerships, government agencies and private organizations work together to develop and finance affordable housing projects. This can help to leverage resources and expertise to create more affordable housing options.

Vacant Lot Rehabilitation: Vacant lots in urban areas can be rehabilitated to provide affordable housing. This can involve building small homes or apartments on the lots, or creating community gardens or other community spaces. By rehabilitating vacant lots, cities can increase the availability of affordable housing and improve the overall quality of life for residents.
